channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Republicans aim to pass Trump's big bill. And, Steve Bannon analyzes Trump's strategy
item.description: House Republicans are focused on passing Trump's "big beautiful bill" by Memorial Day. And, Steve Bannon shows support for Trump's agenda in an interview with NPR's Steve Inskeep.
item.content:encoded:
House Republicans are focused on passing Trump's "big beautiful bill" by Memorial Day. And, Steve Bannon shows support for Trump's agenda in an interview with NPR's Steve Inskeep.

(Image credit: Scott Olson)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: With a focus on unity, Vietnam celebrates 50 years since war's end
item.description: A focus away from the past and on how the private sector can lead future economic growth underscored celebrations in the capital of the former South Vietnam.
item.content:encoded:
A focus away from the past and on how the private sector can lead future economic growth underscored celebrations in the capital of the former South Vietnam.

(Image credit: Manan Vatsyayana)
item.dc:creator: Nga Pham

item.title: More and more older Americans want to know their Alzheimer's status, survey finds
item.description: A survey of 1700 Americans 45 and older found that 79% would want to know if they were in the early stages of Alzheimer's.
item.content:encoded:
A survey of 1700 Americans 45 and older found that 79% would want to know if they were in the early stages of Alzheimer's.

(Image credit: Westend61)
item.dc:creator: Jon Hamilton

item.title: A man chopped down Los Angeles trees. The crime cut deep in the struggling neighborhood
item.description: For days, police say, Samuel Patrick Groft cruised through the streets of Los Angeles on his bicycle, single-handedly chopping down about a dozen city trees with an electric chainsaw in three different neighborhoods.
item.content:encoded:
For days, police say, Samuel Patrick Groft cruised through the streets of Los Angeles on his bicycle, single-handedly chopping down about a dozen city trees with an electric chainsaw in three different neighborhoods.

(Image credit: Jae C. Hong)
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Romo

item.title: Word of the Week: Crimea's tumultuous history shrouds the origin of its very name
item.description: At the northern end of the Black Sea, Crimea sits at the crossroads of Europe and Asia, having been at various times in its long history either coveted, conquered or controlled by various powers.
item.content:encoded:
At the northern end of the Black Sea, Crimea sits at the crossroads of Europe and Asia, having been at various times in its long history either coveted, conquered or controlled by various powers.

(Image credit: Roger Fenton/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: Can charter schools be religious? If so, what does that mean for public education?
item.description: The case could transform public education in the Unites States.
item.content:encoded:
The case could transform public education in the Unites States.

(Image credit: Win McNamee)
item.dc:creator: Nina Totenberg

item.title: How to keep violent porn out of your home and away from your kids
item.description: Kids – even some young kids – are being exposed to an unprecedented amount of pornography online and a lot of it is violent and misogynistic. There are tools parents can use to block this content.
item.content:encoded: Kids – even some young kids – are being exposed to an unprecedented amount of pornography online and a lot of it is violent and misogynistic.  There are tools parents can use to block this content.
item.dc:creator: Michaeleen Doucleff

item.title: VA research brought CT scans and pacemakers into the world. Now it's at risk of cuts
item.description: Researchers at the Department of Veterans Affairs warn that crucial medical research is in jeopardy unless the Trump administration reverses course on cuts.
item.content:encoded:
Researchers at the Department of Veterans Affairs warn that crucial medical research is in jeopardy unless the Trump administration reverses course on cuts.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Quil Lawrence

item.title: Steve Bannon praises Trump's strategy, wants DOGE's receipts
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Trump ally Steve Bannon about the president's agenda at home and abroad.
item.content:encoded:
NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Trump ally Steve Bannon about the president's agenda at home and abroad.

(Image credit: Nickolai Hammar/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Steve Inskeep

item.title: In first 100 days, Trump tests limits, creates chaos and turns from allies
item.description: From foreign policy and tariffs to immigration changes and targeting of DEI, here's a look back at some of the major moves made in the past 100 days of President Trump's second administration.
item.content:encoded:
From foreign policy and tariffs to immigration changes and targeting of DEI, here's a look back at some of the major moves made in the past 100 days of President Trump's second administration.

(Image credit: Alex Brandon)
item.dc:creator: Domenico Montanaro
